newsitem.title: USA: Clinton to seek fast track trade powers in autumn.
newsitem.headline: Clinton to seek fast track trade powers in autumn.

text.p: President Bill Clinton will wait until autumn to ask Congress for authority to negotiate new trade agreements, White House officials said on Friday.

Clinton, who hopes to expand the North American Free Trade Agreement to other nations in Latin America, has decided to delay submitting legislation for so-called fast track trade authority "so we can get more support in Congress," one official said.

Fast track trade authority would allow the administration to negotiate trade agreements without the fear that Congress might later change them. Congress could accept or reject the trade agreements, but could not amend them.
Clinton wants to negotiate an expansion of NAFTA -- which currently includes the United States, Mexico and Canada -- to include Chile, as well as other nations.
There has been stiff opposition in Congress to such an expansion, forcing White House officials to abandon hopes that the legislation could be submitted in June.

Opponents of NAFTA, including some organised labour leaders, have complained that the agreement has spawned a rapid rise in the U.S. trade deficit with Mexico, a loss of jobs from manfacturing moving south and lower wages for workers.
